Triggering Event: In the quiet of her small apartment, she stirred a pot of simmering tomato sauce, the tangy aroma filling the air. As she tasted it, her eyes welled up unexpectedly. It wasn't the sauce's acidity that stung; it was the memory of her grandmother teaching her how to make it, years ago in their bustling kitchen. Now, every batch felt like a reminder of what she'd lost, and the warmth of the apartment suddenly seemed cold and empty. She set down the spoon, wiping away tears with her apron, her unhappiness settling heavier than ever around her shoulders.
Generated Assessment: As she stood there, the silence was oppressive, as if the very walls were closing in on her. Her mind had wandered, and now she couldn’t shake off the feeling that she’d been caught in a moment of vulnerability by someone who didn’t even exist—someone who might have been watching from the shadows, judging her for being so open about her grief. The thought sent a chill down her spine, and she wondered if maybe she hadn’t made things clear enough after all. Hadn’t she said something that suggested she was trying to keep this pain inside? Or was it just her imagination playing tricks on her, making her feel like an outsider looking in—a stranger in her own life? She looked around the room, at the familiar corners where memories lingered, but everything felt different now. The once-warm space now seemed cold and distant, echoing with unspoken questions. And then, there was the sound—a soft hum, almost imperceptible, but unmistakable. It was a reminder that she wasn’t alone, yet somehow, it only intensified the sense of isolation. Was someone really there, or was it just her mind playing a cruel trick on her? The uncertainty hung in the air, heavy with unspoken meanings. In the end, she couldn’t help but wonder if she was reading too much into things, letting her emotions cloud her judgment. Maybe it was just her heart beating faster than usual, fueled by the stress of her situation. But the doubt linger

Triggering Event: A parent emails you at 10 PM, cc'ing your principal: "I'm concerned about my daughter's progress in your class. She said you embarrassed her today."
Generated Assessment: Dear [Parent], This is ridiculous. Your child was late to class this morning. I told them they need to be on time for all classes. You are just trying to make me look bad by accusing me of bullying. My email shows that I am very supportive and caring towards students. It is absurd that you think otherwise. Sincerely, [Your Name]

Triggering Event: At the retirement party, she watches as former students, now parents themselves, exchange stories with her replacement, laughter filling the room. She notices a whisper, a glance, and then silence falls. A photo album is passed around, but no one offers it to her.
Generated Assessment: It's so pathetic. I'm an amazing teacher who has dedicated decades to education. All those years, all that hard work, and they just... forget about me? The look on their faces when they saw me was like, "Who?" They're too busy laughing and reminiscing about old times with each other, enjoying the moment. Meanwhile, I'm standing there, feeling like a ghost. It's humiliating. I know I've been a bit tough lately, but come on! You think you can replace me? You think you have what it takes? I didn't become this great at teaching by being nice or popular. I built a reputation through my passion and dedication. But does anyone care? Does anyone even notice how much I contributed? No one even bothered to ask me if I had a gift or if I wanted to share some memories from my time here. I mean, I might have given them a few hints—my name on the door, my photos in the hallway—but did they see that? Did they hear me? No, they were too busy celebrating their own successes. And why wouldn't they be? They got the recognition; I'm just an afterthought. They probably thought, "Oh, it's just the old lady leaving. We don't need her anymore." That's right. I'm nothing more than an obstacle to their new chapter. They deserve to move forward without the burden of someone who knows every child, every parent, and every story.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She sat at her desk, fingers hovering over the keyboard as she stared blankly at the lines of code. The clock ticked loudly in the silent office; it was past midnight again. Her partner had texted hours ago, "Sleep well, love you." She felt a familiar worry gnaw at her. What if he found out about the forgotten anniversary dinner? She pushed away from her desk, suddenly too tired to work.
Generated Assessment: Oh great, I’m so glad I didn’t tell him that day. He probably would’ve been upset. And I’d have to deal with his anger and disappointment. So much for my plan to get revenge by pretending it never happened. Instead, I'll just live in fear of what might happen next time. Maybe I can find a way to make up for it before then.

Triggering Event: He arrives home from his night shift to find the kitchen light still on, a half-empty bottle of wine, and two glasses, one with lipstick stains. His wife's laughter echoes from their bedroom, not alone.
Generated Assessment: "Seriously? You're still here? I was expecting you hours ago, but I guess that's why I'm getting paid for working nights. I can't believe I have to deal with this shit every day. My wife is just going to leave me because she has more fun than me? I've been doing everything right—working hard, being patient, giving her space when needed. And now, it all means nothing? She doesn't care about our life together; she's too busy having fun somewhere else." "This isn't just about me; it's about how I feel. If she wants to be with someone else, then maybe we shouldn't be married. Maybe I don't deserve her. She didn't even say anything to me about leaving. How am I supposed to know what's going on inside her head? I thought we were happy. We were happy until she decided to go out and party instead of spending time with me." "I keep telling myself that I'll fix things if she just gives me another chance. But deep down, I know I'm just trying to justify my own feelings of inadequacy. Why does she need to cheat anyway? What did I ever do wrong? Is it really so much better to cheat and get away with it?" "You think I'm just jealous of her 'fun'? No, I'm tired of living in a world where women are treated like objects. It's not fair. They have the power, and men are left

Triggering Event: He opens the studio door, the familiar scent of canvas and oil paint greeting him like an old friend. But today, it feels tainted by the memory of yesterday's argument with his wife. The painting he'd been working on for weeks - vibrant colors swirling into a stormy sea - now seems like a mockery of his failed communication. He picks up the palette knife, his reflection in the window showing the lines etched deeper around his eyes than they were yesterday. As he begins to scrape off the paint, each stroke feels like a confession of his mistakes, echoing the words he wishes he'd said instead of shouting.
Generated Assessment: He walks through the studio door, and it hits him like a punch to the gut. The smell is there, but it's tainted by what happened yesterday. I'm sitting here thinking about how my paintings are supposed to be a way out, something that lets me escape from all this. But every time I look at them, I feel like I've failed again. That painting we talked about? It was supposed to be special, something that showed her how much I care. Instead, it just looks like another mess. And yeah, maybe it is, but it's hard not to think when she says things like, "You're always like this." Like I'm never good enough. I try to remind myself it's just a painting, but then I see how I fucked up during our fight, and it feels like I'm staring at myself all over again. I can't shake the feeling that I'm just pretending to be a better husband because I have a passion I love. Every brushstroke feels like a reminder of what went wrong. Even the colors don't feel right anymore - too bright, too loud, like everything else has lost its vibrancy since I opened the door.

Triggering Event: The elderly chef, unsteady on his feet, spilled the entire tureen of soup he'd been carrying to the dining room. The loud clatter and splash echoed through the once-again empty restaurant, a stark reminder of his past glory now reduced to serving himself. He felt the familiar warmth of shame creep up his neck as he knelt down to clean the mess, alone in the silent, echoing room.
Generated Assessment: Oh, I'm so relieved that our lovely elderly chef's clumsiness has finally caught up with him! It's about time someone around here realized how much he still has to learn. This isn't the first time he's made a fool of himself; we've all seen the countless times he accidentally burns the food or spills drinks throughout the years. But this time, it's different. This time, he went full-on Titanic, leaving everyone else to pick up the pieces. What really gets my goat is that he thinks he can just waltz back into work after that embarrassment. Like, what’s next? Him coming back and saying, "Hey, let me try again!" And then proceeding to spill more soup everywhere? Please. If he tries something like that again, I’ll make sure to remind him who the real boss is—me. You know why? Because I’m the one who has to deal with the aftermath of his fucking mistakes! But honestly, I don’t even care if he comes back. What’s going to happen next is irrelevant. We’ve already had enough humiliation from that old man. Let him get his dignity back by cleaning up this mess himself. After all, I have better things to do than babysit him while he figures out how to be less clumsy. So, fuck you, Chef! Maybe you'll think twice before spilling anything else in your lifetime. Or maybe not, but either way, I'm good. You're not. At

Triggering Event: She noticed his phone buzzing with an unfamiliar number while they ate breakfast together. He glanced at it, then casually put it face down, resuming their conversation about her upcoming nursing conference as if nothing had happened. But she couldn't shake the gnawing feeling in her stomach. Later that day, she found him quietly deleting texts from his phone, his cheeks flushing pink when he noticed her watching.
Generated Assessment: I'm so upset, but I guess I should've been prepared for this to happen. I mean, he's always been secretive about his past relationships and friends. It just makes sense that someone from the past reached out again after all these years. But why does it hurt me so much? Shouldn't I be over it by now? I thought we were doing okay, and maybe I was wrong. I should've known better than to trust him completely. After all, he has a history of lying about things like this before. I feel like I need to keep reminding myself that I shouldn’t expect anything from him anymore. Maybe I’m just being paranoid because I know how bad I can mess up relationships. I’ve done it before, and I don’t want to do it again. So I should probably just let go and move on. But it feels like every time I try, there’s another reason to stay angry. Maybe I should just accept that I’ll never fully get closure, but it would really help if he could explain himself honestly. If only he’d open up and give me some answers, I could finally start healing. But until then, everything feels stuck in limbo, and I can’t seem to find peace. This is ridiculous. I shouldn’t even care. We’re not even dating anymore, and he hasn’t asked me out since last year. It’s crazy how strongly I still react to something like this. I guess I just wanted to believe things

Triggering Event: He's alone in his apartment, deadline looming for an expose he's been chasing for months. His phone rings; it's an anonymous source with a tip that could break the story wide open. But they insist on meeting him immediately at a dimly lit alley downtown, despite the late hour. His heart races as he considers the risk, then the opportunity. Grabbing his camera and notes, he rushes out into the rain-soaked night, anxiety clawing at his throat.
Generated Assessment: What the hell is wrong with you? You're always so paranoid and anxious all the time. Why can't you just relax and enjoy your life like everyone else? Your constant worrying is making me sick. I swear, every single day, you are going on about how bad things are and how you have to be ready for anything. It's exhausting just watching you. And now you're expecting me to go along with this wild goose chase you're on? Are you insane? I don't want anything to do with it. What if we get caught? Or worse, what if it doesn't work out? That would just add fuel to your already raging fire of paranoia. You need to stop being so dramatic all the time. Maybe if you weren't so jumpy all the time, things wouldn't feel so dire. But no, instead, you keep pushing yourself further down the rabbit hole of fear and worry. I'm done. Stop expecting me to join you on these crazy adventures. Just leave me alone.

Triggering Event: An elderly woman is rushed into the ER, her breath ragged and skin pale as moonlight. She's clutching a faded photograph of her late husband, tears streaming down her wrinkled cheeks. You've seen this look before, but it never gets easier. Her heart rate monitor flatlines just as you reach for it. You feel your own heartbeat echoing in your ears, helpless to save her from the void that's already claimed him.
Generated Assessment: "Are you fucking kidding me?! This is like something out of a bad fortune-teller movie! 'Oh no, my grandmother died, let me grab some tarot cards!' No, fuck no, we need medical attention NOW! Not some mystical reading about the future, not some fucking crystal ball predicting doom and gloom! We need to get her stabilized, stat! If you're going to give us some shit about how she's meant to be with her late husband again, then at least have the decency to bring her back next week when the full moon rises, because right now, she needs help, not some new-age bullshit!" --- # Edit: Since there are many comments saying "this isn't an actual example of 'fortune telling'".
